title: The Apprentice's Michelle Dewberry was "on the edge of killing herself" until mum's intervention
text:
The Apprentice's Michelle Dewberry was "on the edge of killing herself" until mum's intervention Share Get celebs   Thank you for subscribing!   
Former The Apprentice winner turned TV presenter Michelle Dewberry has candidly revealed she became so depressed five years ago that she decided to end her own life. 
The businesswoman, who won the second series of Lord Sugar’s BBC show in 2006, even told her mother she was “on the edge of killing herself” after falling into a deep depression that came to a head in summer 2012. 
“Some years ago I made a decision to end my life. It was a decision that I took heavily over a period of time and one which came about after years of unhappiness,” she said. 
“Luckily I was persuaded to seek medical help and I duly went to the doctors where I asked to be voluntarily sectioned. Instead I was put on a care plan, given antidepressants and offered therapy,” she continued on Sky News discussion show The Pledge. Michelle Dewberry credits her mum for saving her life (Photo: FameFlynet) Michelle Dewberry once the second series of The Apprentice (Photo: PA) Read More ''I thought it was a persistent pimple'': Ex-Apprentice winner Michelle Dewberry reveals she has skin cancer 
She’s now speaking out to stop what she believes is a stigma surrounding open and frank discussion of mental health. 
“I was in a position where I was really, really sad for a long time and I didn’t want to carry on with life and wanted to die. I didn’t talk to anyone because I didn’t realise I had an issue,” she said. 
“I didn’t just wake up one morning and think, ‘This is the day I commit suicide.’ I was desperately unhappy. I just knew I wanted to end my own life. It got to the point when I thought, I can’t carry on like this,” she told The Sun on Sunday . Michelle sought help for depression after a talk with her mum (Photo: Getty) Read More Apprentice winner Alana on Lord Sugar: 'I think he admires people that go out and do it for themselves' 
“I knew it was not right. I thought I was a burden, I was in deep pain. I was desperate. the thought of ending my life was constant for months. So one day I just knew I had to go round to my mum’s in Hull and I told her I was on the edge of killing myself. She was devastated.” 
But it was that talk with her mum that saved Michelle’s life. 
The presenter explained how her mum’s intervention made her book a doctor’s appointment, which led her to understand she’d been suffering depression for years. 
Michelle said: “She was my rock, my guardian angel. It was a talk with her that made me realise that I had depression. I was very lucky.” Michelle now works with people struggling with depression (Photo: PA) Read More Where are The Apprentices now? As the show returns we take a look at the previous winners 
She now works with various charities and mentors people with depression. She spoke out about her own experiences in a bid to combat what she sees as a stigma surrounding mental health. 
“I remain grateful for that intervention because it literally saved my life but it only happened after I decided to talk and if people felt less embarrassed or ashamed, less worried about their jobs, reactions of family and friends, more people would be able to talk,” she added on The Pledge. 
“This stigma about mental health need to end now because it is literally killing people.” Like us on Facebook
